references:
Implementation details: We follow the input format and data augmentation as described in [2], conducting all experiments using the â€œvit_bâ€ version of SAM on an NVIDIA A100-SXM4-40GB GPU.
The input to the model is of size (NÃ—HÃ—Wğ‘ğ»ğ‘ŠN\times H\times W), which consists of every set of Nğ‘N consecutive slices (N=5ğ‘5N=5).
In LoRA, we initialize matrix Ağ´A from a random Gaussian distribution while setting matrix BğµB to zero and rank to 323232.
The fine-tuning process employs a hybrid segmentation loss, combining cross-entropy loss and Dice loss as â„’sâ€‹eâ€‹g=Î±â€‹â„’Câ€‹E+Î²â€‹â„’Dâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹esuperscriptâ„’ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ›¼superscriptâ„’ğ¶ğ¸ğ›½superscriptâ„’ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘’\mathcal{L}^{seg}=\alpha\mathcal{L}^{CE}+\beta\mathcal{L}^{Dice}, with weighting factors Î±=0.2ğ›¼0.2\alpha=0.2 and Î²=0.8ğ›½0.8\beta=0.8 following [32].
The training utilizes the Adam optimizer with a batch size of 32.
We compare federated learning with localized (using client-owned data alone) and centralized (all data pooled) settings. We test each site data separately for all fine-tuning strategies, and the results are tabulated in TableÂ 1.

We also benchmark FLAP-SAM against MA-SAM [2], which uses a 3D adapter along with FacT for fine-tuning. We perform this comparison only in the centralized setting because the decomposition of Î”â€‹WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta W back to FacT-Tensor-Train or FacT-Tucker formats [13] after federated aggregation is not straightforward. Although MA-SAM produces comparable results to our method (see Table 1) in a centralized setting, it uses 28.728.728.7M trainable parameters (âˆ¼similar-to\sim16Ã—16\times more than our method).
This validates our choice of using LoRA, which is both parameter-efficient and FL-friendly.

references:
Our proposed FLAP-SAM method achieves 6%percent66\% absolute improvement in Dice score compared to the FullFT approach, with a âˆ¼similar-to\sim49Ã—49\times reduction in communication overhead on Fed-KITS. Due to the small size of the dataset, the FullFT approach easily results in overfitting, highlighting the importance of using PEFT methods in limited data settings [3].
The Attention fine-tuning (AttnFT) only achieves half of our improvement (2.8%percent2.82.8\% less than FLAP-SAM) and still incurs âˆ¼similar-to\sim17Ã—17\times more communication cost than our method. Both LoRAFT and PDecFT are more efficient but have lower Dice scores than our method.
The LoRADecFT achieves an equivalent dice score to our method, but our method is âˆ¼similar-to\sim2.8Ã—2.8\times more efficient regarding parameters and communication.
We conduct ablation on the rank parameter of LoRA in FL, and the results are shown in TableÂ 2. We observe that a lower LoRA rank significantly reduces the trainable parameters with a marginal degradation in the Dice score. We also conduct experiments with other low-rank adapters like DoRA[19] and MoLE[30], which only show marginal performance differences among the adapters.

references:
Segmentation is one of the cornerstone tasks in modern medical image analysis for automated diagnosis and disease monitoring. While the advent of foundational models has pushed the boundaries of the state-of-the-art in many computer vision applications, such benefits are yet to transfer fully to the medical imaging domain [33]. For example, the Segment Anything Model (SAM) [14] has an excellent zero-shot generalization to new distributions and tasks involving natural images. However, the SAM model fails to generalize well across diverse medical imaging modalities due to the insurmountable distribution shifts [11]. Works like [6, 10] highlight a substantial performance gap between the zero-shot inference and training on domain-specific medical images despite using various prompts in SAM.
MSA [29] and SAM-Med2D [4] improve SAM by using tailored prompting techniques in 2D medical images. However, creating such prompts for each 2D slice of 3D data is labor-intensive.

Implementation details: We follow the input format and data augmentation as described in [2], conducting all experiments using the â€œvit_bâ€ version of SAM on an NVIDIA A100-SXM4-40GB GPU.
The input to the model is of size (NÃ—HÃ—Wğ‘ğ»ğ‘ŠN\times H\times W), which consists of every set of Nğ‘N consecutive slices (N=5ğ‘5N=5).
In LoRA, we initialize matrix Ağ´A from a random Gaussian distribution while setting matrix BğµB to zero and rank to 323232.
The fine-tuning process employs a hybrid segmentation loss, combining cross-entropy loss and Dice loss as â„’sâ€‹eâ€‹g=Î±â€‹â„’Câ€‹E+Î²â€‹â„’Dâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹esuperscriptâ„’ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ›¼superscriptâ„’ğ¶ğ¸ğ›½superscriptâ„’ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘’\mathcal{L}^{seg}=\alpha\mathcal{L}^{CE}+\beta\mathcal{L}^{Dice}, with weighting factors Î±=0.2ğ›¼0.2\alpha=0.2 and Î²=0.8ğ›½0.8\beta=0.8 following [32].
The training utilizes the Adam optimizer with a batch size of 32.
We compare federated learning with localized (using client-owned data alone) and centralized (all data pooled) settings. We test each site data separately for all fine-tuning strategies, and the results are tabulated in TableÂ 1.

Our proposed FLAP-SAM method achieves 6%percent66\% absolute improvement in Dice score compared to the FullFT approach, with a âˆ¼similar-to\sim49Ã—49\times reduction in communication overhead on Fed-KITS. Due to the small size of the dataset, the FullFT approach easily results in overfitting, highlighting the importance of using PEFT methods in limited data settings [3].
The Attention fine-tuning (AttnFT) only achieves half of our improvement (2.8%percent2.82.8\% less than FLAP-SAM) and still incurs âˆ¼similar-to\sim17Ã—17\times more communication cost than our method. Both LoRAFT and PDecFT are more efficient but have lower Dice scores than our method.
The LoRADecFT achieves an equivalent dice score to our method, but our method is âˆ¼similar-to\sim2.8Ã—2.8\times more efficient regarding parameters and communication.
We conduct ablation on the rank parameter of LoRA in FL, and the results are shown in TableÂ 2. We observe that a lower LoRA rank significantly reduces the trainable parameters with a marginal degradation in the Dice score. We also conduct experiments with other low-rank adapters like DoRA[19] and MoLE[30], which only show marginal performance differences among the adapters.

We also benchmark FLAP-SAM against MA-SAM [2], which uses a 3D adapter along with FacT for fine-tuning. We perform this comparison only in the centralized setting because the decomposition of Î”â€‹WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta W back to FacT-Tensor-Train or FacT-Tucker formats [13] after federated aggregation is not straightforward. Although MA-SAM produces comparable results to our method (see Table 1) in a centralized setting, it uses 28.728.728.7M trainable parameters (âˆ¼similar-to\sim16Ã—16\times more than our method).
This validates our choice of using LoRA, which is both parameter-efficient and FL-friendly.

Segmentation is one of the cornerstone tasks in modern medical image analysis for automated diagnosis and disease monitoring. While the advent of foundational models has pushed the boundaries of the state-of-the-art in many computer vision applications, such benefits are yet to transfer fully to the medical imaging domain [33]. For example, the Segment Anything Model (SAM) [14] has an excellent zero-shot generalization to new distributions and tasks involving natural images. However, the SAM model fails to generalize well across diverse medical imaging modalities due to the insurmountable distribution shifts [11]. Works like [6, 10] highlight a substantial performance gap between the zero-shot inference and training on domain-specific medical images despite using various prompts in SAM.
MSA [29] and SAM-Med2D [4] improve SAM by using tailored prompting techniques in 2D medical images. However, creating such prompts for each 2D slice of 3D data is labor-intensive.

Implementation details: We follow the input format and data augmentation as described in [2], conducting all experiments using the â€œvit_bâ€ version of SAM on an NVIDIA A100-SXM4-40GB GPU.
The input to the model is of size (NÃ—HÃ—Wğ‘ğ»ğ‘ŠN\times H\times W), which consists of every set of Nğ‘N consecutive slices (N=5ğ‘5N=5).
In LoRA, we initialize matrix Ağ´A from a random Gaussian distribution while setting matrix BğµB to zero and rank to 323232.

The training utilizes the Adam optimizer with a batch size of 32.
We compare federated learning with localized (using client-owned data alone) and centralized (all data pooled) settings. We test each site data separately for all fine-tuning strategies, and the results are tabulated in TableÂ 1.

Our proposed FLAP-SAM method achieves 6%percent66\% absolute improvement in Dice score compared to the FullFT approach, with a âˆ¼similar-to\sim49Ã—49\times reduction in communication overhead on Fed-KITS. Due to the small size of the dataset, the FullFT approach easily results in overfitting, highlighting the importance of using PEFT methods in limited data settings [3].

The LoRADecFT achieves an equivalent dice score to our method, but our method is âˆ¼similar-to\sim2.8Ã—2.8\times more efficient regarding parameters and communication.

references:
Segmentation is one of the cornerstone tasks in modern medical image analysis for automated diagnosis and disease monitoring. While the advent of foundational models has pushed the boundaries of the state-of-the-art in many computer vision applications, such benefits are yet to transfer fully to the medical imaging domain [33]. For example, the Segment Anything Model (SAM) [14] has an excellent zero-shot generalization to new distributions and tasks involving natural images. However, the SAM model fails to generalize well across diverse medical imaging modalities due to the insurmountable distribution shifts [11]. Works like [6, 10] highlight a substantial performance gap between the zero-shot inference and training on domain-specific medical images despite using various prompts in SAM.
MSA [29] and SAM-Med2D [4] improve SAM by using tailored prompting techniques in 2D medical images. However, creating such prompts for each 2D slice of 3D data is labor-intensive.

Implementation details: We follow the input format and data augmentation as described in [2], conducting all experiments using the â€œvit_bâ€ version of SAM on an NVIDIA A100-SXM4-40GB GPU.
The input to the model is of size (NÃ—HÃ—Wğ‘ğ»ğ‘ŠN\times H\times W), which consists of every set of Nğ‘N consecutive slices (N=5ğ‘5N=5).
In LoRA, we initialize matrix Ağ´A from a random Gaussian distribution while setting matrix BğµB to zero and rank to 323232.
The fine-tuning process employs a hybrid segmentation loss, combining cross-entropy loss and Dice loss as â„’sâ€‹eâ€‹g=Î±â€‹â„’Câ€‹E+Î²â€‹â„’Dâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹esuperscriptâ„’ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ›¼superscriptâ„’ğ¶ğ¸ğ›½superscriptâ„’ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘’\mathcal{L}^{seg}=\alpha\mathcal{L}^{CE}+\beta\mathcal{L}^{Dice}, with weighting factors Î±=0.2ğ›¼0.2\alpha=0.2 and Î²=0.8ğ›½0.8\beta=0.8 following [32].
The training utilizes the Adam optimizer with a batch size of 32.
We compare federated learning with localized (using client-owned data alone) and centralized (all data pooled) settings. We test each site data separately for all fine-tuning strategies, and the results are tabulated in TableÂ 1.

Our proposed FLAP-SAM method achieves 6%percent66\% absolute improvement in Dice score compared to the FullFT approach, with a âˆ¼similar-to\sim49Ã—49\times reduction in communication overhead on Fed-KITS. Due to the small size of the dataset, the FullFT approach easily results in overfitting, highlighting the importance of using PEFT methods in limited data settings [3].
The Attention fine-tuning (AttnFT) only achieves half of our improvement (2.8%percent2.82.8\% less than FLAP-SAM) and still incurs âˆ¼similar-to\sim17Ã—17\times more communication cost than our method. Both LoRAFT and PDecFT are more efficient but have lower Dice scores than our method.
The LoRADecFT achieves an equivalent dice score to our method, but our method is âˆ¼similar-to\sim2.8Ã—2.8\times more efficient regarding parameters and communication.
We conduct ablation on the rank parameter of LoRA in FL, and the results are shown in TableÂ 2. We observe that a lower LoRA rank significantly reduces the trainable parameters with a marginal degradation in the Dice score. We also conduct experiments with other low-rank adapters like DoRA[19] and MoLE[30], which only show marginal performance differences among the adapters.

We also benchmark FLAP-SAM against MA-SAM [2], which uses a 3D adapter along with FacT for fine-tuning. We perform this comparison only in the centralized setting because the decomposition of Î”â€‹WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta W back to FacT-Tensor-Train or FacT-Tucker formats [13] after federated aggregation is not straightforward. Although MA-SAM produces comparable results to our method (see Table 1) in a centralized setting, it uses 28.728.728.7M trainable parameters (âˆ¼similar-to\sim16Ã—16\times more than our method).
This validates our choice of using LoRA, which is both parameter-efficient and FL-friendly.
